blog.name: cleowho
blog.title: Flight Through Eternity
blog.description:
Classic Doctor Who / Contemporary Doctor Who blog by Chloe "Cleo" Mortimer.
British fan girl and obsessive Whonatic. Tweets @CleoWho
All posts created exclusively by me unless they're marked as reblogs. Expect SPOILERS, because you can't enthuse over fifty years of a TV show and keep everything that's happened a secret.
Comments and opinions are entirely my own. Original text entries are copyright (c) Chloe Mortimer.

summary: 50% of all Good Omens fanfiction is written by Michael Sheen. David Tennant writes 45% of it but has his wife post it because he...
body: 50% of all Good Omens fanfiction is written by Michael Sheen. David Tennant writes 45% of it but has his wife post it because he can’t figure out how, 3% is written by Neil Gaiman (who may or may not be possessed by the ghost of Terry Pratchett), and the remaining 2% is written by the fandom.

reblog.comment: 50% of all Good Omens fanfiction is written by Michael Sheen. David Tennant writes 45% of it but has his wife post it because he can’t figure out how, 3% is written by Neil Gaiman (who may or may not be possessed by the ghost of Terry Pratchett), and the remaining 2% is written by the fandom.

trail.content_raw: 50% of all Good Omens fanfiction is written by Michael Sheen. David Tennant writes 45% of it but has his wife post it because he can’t figure out how, 3% is written by Neil Gaiman (who may or may not be possessed by the ghost of Terry Pratchett), and the remaining 2% is written by the fandom.
trail.content: 50% of all Good Omens fanfiction is written by Michael Sheen. David Tennant writes 45% of it but has his wife post it because he can’t figure out how, 3% is written by Neil Gaiman (who may or may not be possessed by the ghost of Terry Pratchett), and the remaining 2% is written by the fandom.

summary:
Behind the Scene of The Waters of Mars (Part 11)

  Excerpt from TV Guide’s interview with Lindsay Duncan for The Waters of...
caption:
Behind the Scene of The Waters of Mars (Part 11)

Excerpt from TV Guide’s interview with Lindsay Duncan for The Waters of Mars:

Lindsay’s thoughts on Incoming Doctor Matt Smith:

I had worked with Matt in a play called That Face.  Matt and I were mother and son in a very intense, dysfunctional relationship. So we became very close.

When his casting was announced [in a special episode of Doctor Who Confidential] I was at home watching alone. I didn’t know whose name they were going to say, and I was very curious because there were so many rumours floating around.

When they said Matt, I screamed at the TV. I texted him straight away because he’d kept it so quiet. I think it’s a brilliant handover from David. Matt’s an amazing actor. I know he hasn’t had David’s experience, but he’s got great range and an appetite for the work. It’s very exciting.

Other Waters of Mars behind-the-scenes posts: [ one ] [ two ] [ three ] [ four ] [ five ] [ six ] [ seven ] [ eight ] [ nine ] [ ten ]
Full list of behind-the-scenes posts:  [ here ]

summary: Here’s an older Doctor Who fan art that we recently updated after catching up on the new season. We are really enjoying Jodie...
caption:
Here’s an older Doctor Who fan art that we recently updated after catching up on the new season. We are really enjoying Jodie Whittaker as the new Doctor! But our first doctor, and our favorite is David Tennant, who we had the great pleasure of meeting recently at C2E2! 

Pictured with us is our friends and coworkers from the animation studio we freelance at. Our friend, Ben, the one to the left of David Tennant, introduced us to Doctor Who on our lunch breaks at work. Later, we would all meet up at his place for Friday night Doctor Who viewings. We never thought we’d ever do a celebrity photo, but will always cherish this photo!

reblog.comment:

Our friend, Ben, the one to the left of David Tennant, introduced us to Doctor Who on our lunch breaks at work. Later, we would all meet up at his place for Friday night Doctor Who viewings. We never thought we’d ever do a celebrity photo, but will always cherish this photo!

summary: 365 Marvel Villain paper cut-outs - one villain, every day, all year. April 5th - The Purple Man The deplorable villain known as...
caption:
365 Marvel Villain paper cut-outs - one villain, every day, all year.

April 5th - The Purple Man

The deplorable villain known as The Purple Man had been an industrial spy in Eastern Europe.  An accident resulted in his being exposed to an experimental nerve gas that colored his hair and skin purple and endowed him with the ability to control the will of other.  He used this newfound power to engage in a life of crime, using his persuasive powers to live luxuriously and take whatever he wanted; this included numerous acts of sexual assault where he forced women to be with him.  Relocating to America, The Purple Man came into conflict with Daredevil, Spider-Man, Power Man and Iron Fist.  The Purple Man was later abducted by Dr. Doom and used as part of a grand scheme to take over the world.  Doom had built a power amplifier that he use to exponentially augment The Purple Man’s power of persuasion, utilizing it to make all kneel before Doom.  The Avengers were eventually able to foil Doom’s schemes and The Purple Man was seemingly killed in the aftermath.  Yet it turned out that he had survived and was incarcerated.  He was later able to escape with the aide of Baron Zemo who also sought to use his powers for conquest; the plan was eventually foiled by The Thunderbolts.  At some point during his criminal career, The Purple Man took a special interest in the young hero, Jewel (Jessica Jones).  Bending her will with his powers, The Purple Man essential kept Jones like a pet.  She was ultimately able to escape, yet the experience was so traumatic that Jones chose to retire her identity as a super hero and instead become a private investigator.   The Purple Man returned to once more try to gain control over Jones although this time she was able to resist his powers.  The Purple Man was then shot and killed by Kraven The Hunter.  So to ensure that he never return, Jessica Jones’s friend Captain Marvel took the villain’s body up into space and threw it into the sun.  A version of The Purple Man played a major role in the first season of the Jessica Jones television series where he was portrayed by actor David Tennant.  The Purple Man first appeared in Daredevil Vol. 1 #4.
